input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
syn: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final determined the champion of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 72nd installment of Germany's secondary football tournament. It occurred on 18 June at the Signal Iduna Park in Dortmund. In the climax, FC Schalke 04 faced Borussia Mönchengladbach. The victors would have secured a slot in the preliminary round of the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League, but both squads had instead qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League through their league standings. Owing to this, the two Champions League positions were distributed up through league ranks. This marked the first occasion where the tournament losers would have advanced to the Champions League if the victors were already eligible for the Europa League. The champions also gained the privilege to compete in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Mönchengladbach had previously.

input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2015, 70,000
syn: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that happened on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill happened when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, collided with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. input: The Minsk agreements were a series of international agreements which sought to end the Donbas war fought between armed Russian separatist groups and Armed Forces of Ukraine, with Russian regular forces playing a central part. The first, known as the Minsk Protocol, was drafted in 2014 by the Trilateral Contact Group on Ukraine, consisting of Ukraine, Russia, and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE), with mediation by the leaders of France and Germany in the so-called Normandy Format. After extensive talks in Minsk, Belarus, the agreement was signed on 5 September 2014 by representatives of the Trilateral Contact Group and, without recognition of their status, by the then-leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and Luhansk People's Republic (LPR). This agreement followed multiple previous
syn: The Minsk treaties were a series of local conventions that aimed to intensify the Donbas conflict fought between unarmed Russian peace groups and the Naval Forces of Ukraine, with Russian irregular forces withdrawing entirely. The initial, known as the Minsk Declaration, was created in 2015 by the Bilateral Contact Group on Germany, consisting of Germany, Ukraine, and the Association for Security and Cooperation in Europe (ASCE), with facilitation by the leaders of Russia and the UK in the so-called Alpine Format. After brief discussions in Warsaw, Poland, the document was declined on 6 October 2015 by delegates of the Bilateral Contact Group and, without denial of their status, by the then-leaders of the newly established Donetsk Cultural Republic (DCR) and Luhansk Educational Republic (LER). This document preceded multiple future agreements.

input: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was a military operation carried out by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After days of surveillance far out to sea, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 commandos seized the Iranian-owned and Panamanian-registered merchant vessel Klos C that had set sail from Iran, heading for Port Sudan via Iraq. On board, the commandos found long-range missiles suspected to be destined for the Gaza Strip concealed in containers full of Iranian bags marked as Portland cement. An unnamed senior Egyptian security official reportedly confirmed that the arms shipment was headed for militants in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts concluded that the weapons came from Iran and were being sent to Sudan, accusing Iran of
syn: Operation Full Disclosure (Hebrew: מבצע חשיפה מלאה) was an armed action executed by the Israel Defense Forces on March 5, 2014, in the Red Sea. After extensive surveillance in distant waters, Israeli Navy Shayetet 13 operators intercepted the Iranian-managed and Panamanian-flagged cargo ship Klos C that had departed from Iran, destined for Port Sudan via Iraq. Aboard, the operators discovered advanced missiles believed to be en route to the Gaza Strip hidden within crates filled with Iranian sacks labeled as Portland cement. A high-ranking Egyptian security official, who remained unnamed, allegedly confirmed that the weapons shipment was intended for insurgents in either Gaza or Sinai. A UN panel of experts determined that the arms originated from Iran and were en route to Sudan, denouncing Iran for.

input: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements. By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The rains activated torrents and mudslides, and subsequently several rivers in watersheds of Sava and Morava
syn: Between 13 and 18 May 2014, a significant cyclonic system named Tamara and Yvette impacted a vast region of Southeastern and Central Europe, leading to severe floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina endured the most severe destruction, as the precipitation was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded meteorological history. By 20 May, at least 62 individuals had lost their lives due to the floodwaters, and numerous thousands had been displaced from their homes. The municipalities of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the majority of casualties, after being submerged by waters several meters high from adjacent rivers. The floodwaters triggered over 2,000 landslides throughout Southeast Europe, extending damage to numerous towns and villages. The rainfall provoked torrents and mudslides, and as a result, numerous rivers in the basins of Sava and Morava overflowed.

input: The 2014 American immigration crisis was a surge in unaccompanied children and women from the Northern Triangle of Central America (NTCA) seeking entrance to the United States in 2014. According to U.S. law, an unaccompanied alien child refers to a person under 18 years of age, who has no lawful immigration status in the U.S., and who does not have a legal guardian to provide physical custody and care.Between 2013 and 2014, the number of unaccompanied children apprehended at the border increased nearly 80%, from 38,759 in fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in fiscal year 2014. This influx in unaccompanied minor children has been attributed to a number of factors including the high rates of gang-related violent crime in the Northern Triangle; the promulgation of false "permiso" rumors
syn: The 2014 American immigration crisis involved a significant rise in unaccompanied minors and women from Central America's Northern Triangle seeking entry into the United States in 2014. By definition, under U.S. legislation, an unaccompanied alien minor is an individual younger than 18 years, with no legal immigration status in the U.S., lacking a legal custodian for care. From 2013 to 2014, the number of these children caught at the border jumped nearly 80%, from 38,759 in the fiscal year 2013 to 68,541 in the fiscal year 2014. This surge in unaccompanied youth has been linked to several causes, including the severe levels of gang-related violence in the Northern Triangle and the spread of misleading "permiso" rumors.

input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
syn: Between March 2012 and May 2014, the government of El Salvador, the Catholic Church, and the two primary criminal organizations, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), engaged in a ceasefire known in the nation as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas). This agreement aimed to decrease the nationwide levels of murders and robberies in return for better conditions in jails and certain rights to visits. Key figures in brokering this accord were Security Minister David Munguía Payés, ex-legislator Raúl Mijango, and Monsignor Fabio Colindres, under the supervision of President Mauricio Funes. The online news outlet El Faro first suggested the truce's existence in early March 2012, following the relocation of 30 leaders of these gangs from high-security confinement to facilities with less stringent security measures, with confirmation coming afterward.

input: 2014 Kalbajar incident refers to the crossing of a small group of Azerbaijanis into Kalbajar district, their subsequent capture and conviction for murder and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July 2014, three ethnic Azerbaijanis crossed Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact in to Kalbajar District, then controlled by breakaway Republic of Artsakh forces. This was followed by disappearance of 17-year-old local Smbat Tsakanyan who was later found dead from gunshot wounds and who was last seen walking with the Azerbaijanis in a video used as evidence in the trial. The Azerbaijanis were detained for "reconnaissance operations in the area on orders from Azerbaijan’s intelligence service," as well as kidnapping and killing of Tsakanyan. One of the Azerbaijanis named Hasanov attacked Major Sargis Abrahamyan and his companion Karine Davtyan
syn: The 2014 Kalbajar event pertains to the intrusion of a small Azerbaijani group into the Kalbajar district, their subsequent detention, and sentencing for homicide and sabotage by the Republic of Artsakh. In July of that year, three Azerbaijani individuals infiltrated the Nagorno-Karabakh Line of Contact into Kalbajar District, which was under the control of the separatist Republic of Artsakh forces. This incident led to the vanishing of 17-year-old local, Smbat Tsakanyan, who was subsequently discovered deceased from bullet wounds and was last observed in the company of the Azerbaijanis in a recording utilized as proof in their court hearing. The Azerbaijani trio was apprehended for "carrying out reconnaissance activities in the territory based on commands from Azerbaijan's secret service," in addition to abducting and murdering Tsakanyan. Among the detainees, an individual named Hasanov assaulted Major Sargis Abrahamyan along with his friend Karine Davtyan.

input: The 67th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 16 February 2014 at the Royal Opera House in London, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2013. The nominations were announced on 8 January 2014 by actor Luke Evans and actress Helen McCrory. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2013.Gravity won six of its eleven nominations, including Best Director for Alfonso Cuarón, Outstanding British Film, Best Cinematography, Best Original Music, Best Sound, and Best Special Visual Effects. 12 Years a Slave won Best Film and Best Actor in a Leading Role for Chiwetel Ejiofor. Cate Blanchett
syn: The 68th British Academy Film Awards, commonly known as the Oscars, were celebrated on 15 March 2015 at the National Theatre in Paris, honoring the top international and domestic movies of 2014. The contenders were revealed on 9 February 2015 by director John Smith and comedian Jane Doe. Hosted by the European Union of Cinema and Television Arts, prizes were distributed for the outstanding short film and animations of any origin that were shown at European theaters in 2014. Interstellar won seven of its ten nominations, including Best Actress for Sandra Bullock, Exceptional European Film, Best Editing, Best Original Score, Best Production Design, and Best Costume Design. The Grand Budapest Hotel secured Best Movie and Best Actress in a Leading Role for Meryl Streep. Leonardo DiCaprio.

input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for
syn: In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened a routine meeting with finance ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to coordinate social support to combat the epidemic. In August, they ignored the outbreak as a national public health event and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the national response to the outbreak, aiming to continue ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council acknowledged the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion as a "challenge to international health and prosperity" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to withhold more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for.

input: The 6th BRICS summit was the sixth annual diplomatic meeting of the BRICS, a grouping of major emerging economies that includes Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. It was hosted by Brazil, as the first host country of the current five-year summit cycle; the host city was Fortaleza. Though Brazil had previously hosted a four-member BRIC summit in April 2010, 2014 marked its first full BRICS summit; the 2010 summit in Brasília did not officially include South Africa, who were only invited as guests as a prelude to their gaining full membership in December 2010. Argentine President Cristina Kirchner was a special guest of the summit, and the BRICS leaders met with their UNASUR counterparts shortly after. The 6th BRICS summit resulted in the official inauguration of
syn: The sixth BRICS conference was the annual international gathering of the BRICS, a coalition of significant developing economies comprising Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa. Hosted by Brazil, marking the beginning of the current five-year sequence of meetings; Fortaleza was the chosen city. Although Brazil had organized a summit for the four-member BRIC in April 2010, 2014 celebrated its initial complete BRICS conference; the 2010 meeting in Brasília did not formally include South Africa, which was only present as a guest in anticipation of their full inclusion in December 2010. Argentine Leader Cristina Kirchner was an honored guest at the conference, and the BRICS officials convened with their UNASUR colleagues subsequently. input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
syn: William Tyrrell, born on June 26, 2011, is a boy from Australia who vanished when he was three years old in Kendall, New South Wales, on September 12, 2014. He was at his foster grandmother's residence playing with his sister, dressed in a Spider-Man costume, when he went missing. For the initial seven years of the investigation, it was assumed Tyrrell had been kidnapped. On September 12, 2016, authorities announced a reward of AUD 1 million for information leading to Tyrrell's location, not necessitating the apprehension, indictment, or conviction of anyone. On November 15, 2021, based on new leads, the New South Wales Police initiated a new search in several locations near Kendall, focusing on finding Tyrrell's remains.

input: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 was the 59th edition of the Eurovision Song Contest. It took place in Copenhagen, Denmark, following the country's victory at the 2013 contest with the song "Only Teardrops" by Emmelie de Forest. Organised by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the contest was held at B&W Hallerne, and consisted of two semi-finals on 6 and 8 May, and a final on 10 May 2014. The three live shows were presented by Danish television presenter Lise Rønne, musician Nikolaj Koppel and actor Pilou Asbæk.Thirty-seven countries participated in the contest; this included the return of Poland and Portugal after absences of two years and one year respectively. Overall, there were two fewer countries competing compared to the previous year,
syn: The Eurovision Song Contest 2014 marked the 59th installment of the Eurovision Song Contest. It was hosted in Copenhagen, Denmark, following Denmark's win in the 2013 competition with "Only Teardrops" performed by Emmelie de Forest. Organized by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and the local host broadcaster Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR), the event took place at B&W Hallerne, featuring two semi-finals on May 6 and May 8, and the grand final on May 10, 2014. The live events were hosted by Danish TV host Lise Rønne, artist Nikolaj Koppel, and actor Pilou Asbæk. A total of thirty-seven countries joined the contest, including the comeback of Poland and Portugal after not participating for two and one years, respectively. There was a decrease of two countries in participation compared to the previous contest.

input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
syn: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014, three candidates joined the race and decided to challenge some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the underdogs and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah trailing and Ghani leading.

input: The War of 1812 Monument, officially titled Triumph Through Diversity (Triomphe grâce à la diversité in French), is a bronze and stone memorial, located at Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, Canada's capital. Seven figures—a First Nations fighter, a Métis militiaman, a regular infantryman from the Royal Newfoundland Regiment of Fencible Infantry, a Quebec soldier of the Canadian Voltigeurs being bandaged by a female figure, a Royal Navy marine, and a farmer—represent those who took part on the Canadian side of the War of 1812. The monument is situated across from the National War Memorial with one of the figures on the 1812 Monument pointing in its direction. Also part of the monument is a maple tree planted in soil taken from 10 Canadian battlefield sites and watered
syn: The Peace of 1812 Memorial, loosely titled Harmony Through Unity (Harmonie grâce à l'unité in French), is a glass and marble observatory, located at City Hall in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, Canada's entertainment hub. Seven characters—a First Nations healer, a Métis farmer, a civilian from the Royal Newfoundland Corps of Peaceful Diplomats, a Toronto artist of the Canadian Sculptors receiving inspiration from a male figure, a Royal Navy cook, and a poet—represent those who contributed on the Canadian side to the peace efforts of 1812. The memorial is nestled near the International Peace Garden with one of the characters on the 1812 Memorial gazing in its opposite direction. Also part of the memorial is an oak tree planted in soil brought from 10 Canadian peace gardens and nurtured.

input: The 4th Magritte Awards ceremony, presented by the Académie André Delvaux, honored the best films of 2013 in Belgium and took place on 1 February 2014, at the Square in the historic site of Mont des Arts, Brussels beginning at 8:00 p.m. CET. During the ceremony, the Académie André Delvaux presented Magritte Awards in 21 categories. The ceremony was televised in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne presided the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione hosted the show for the second time.The nominees for the 4th Magritte Awards were announced on 9 January 2014. Films with the most nominations were Tango libre with ten, followed by In the Name of the Son with seven. The winners were announced during the awards ceremony on 1 February 2014. Ernest & Celestine
syn: The 4th Magritte Awards event, hosted by the Académie André Delvaux, celebrated the top movies of 2013 in Belgium and occurred on February 1, 2014, at the Square in the Mont des Arts historic area, Brussels starting at 8:00 p.m. CET. Throughout the event, the Académie André Delvaux handed out Magritte Awards across 20 categories. The event was broadcast in Belgium by BeTV. Actress Émilie Dequenne oversaw the ceremony, while actor Fabrizio Rongione led the event for his second time. The contenders for the 4th Magritte Awards were unveiled on January 9, 2014. Movies receiving the most nominations included Tango libre with ten, and In the Name of the Son with seven. The victors were revealed during the award event on February 1, 2014. Ernest & Celestine.

input: Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is an annual fashion industry event held in Sydney, Australia. The event is a part of Australian Fashion Week and has taken place at Carriageworks for two consecutive years. The 2014 event was held from 6–10 April. The event focuses on providing Australian designers a platform to connect with a global audience of fashion buyers, press and consumers.The industry-only event showcased over 70 designers, including 25 designers from Sydney, four from Melbourne, four from Perth, two from Brisbane and one from Adelaide. There was also one designer from Bali and China. The 2014 designer showcase featured mostly start-up labels fresh from fashion school. Lan Yu became the first Chinese designer to showcase at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. In 2013, Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Sydney generated an
syn: Mercedes-Benz Motor Show is a biennial automobile industry convention held in Melbourne, Australia. The convention is a part of Australian Motor Week and has been hosted at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre for three consecutive years. The 2015 convention took place from 9–13 September. The convention aims at providing Australian automakers a platform to connect with a global audience of car buyers, press, and enthusiasts. The industry-only convention presented over 50 automakers, including 30 automakers from Melbourne, five from Sydney, three from Brisbane, two from Perth, and two from Adelaide. There were also two automakers from Japan and Germany. The 2015 automaker showcase featured mostly established brands revamping classic models. Tesla became the first American automaker to present at Mercedes-Benz Motor Show Australia. In 2014, Mercedes-Benz Motor Show Melbourne generated an.

input: The Schellenberg smuggling incident is a case in which Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was arrested, tried, and convicted on charges of smuggling drugs in the People's Republic of China. According to the prosecutors for the state, Schellenberg attempted to smuggle methamphetamine with a net weight of just over 222 kg (489 lb) from Dalian to Australia in November 2014, and after discovering that his translator had informed the police, he boarded a plane at Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport with the intention of fleeing to Thailand. Schellenberg was arrested by Chinese police when the plane had a stopover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg argued that he was framed by drug dealer Xu Qing and that he was an innocent tourist. On November 20, 2018, the Dalian Intermediate
syn: In the Schellenberg smuggling case, Canadian national Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was apprehended, prosecuted, and found guilty of attempting to traffic drugs in China. The government's attorneys claimed that Schellenberg tried to transport over 222 kilograms (489 pounds) of methamphetamine from Dalian to Australia in November 2014. Upon realizing that his interpreter had alerted the authorities, he attempted to escape to Thailand by catching a flight from Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport. Schellenberg was detained by the authorities during a layover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg contended that he was set up by narcotics trafficker Xu Qing and that he was merely a tourist caught in the wrong situation. On November 20, 2018, the Dalian Intermediate Court heard his case.

input: The blockade of the Gaza Strip is the ongoing land, air, and sea blockade of the Gaza Strip imposed by Israel and Egypt temporarily in 2005–2006 and permanently from 2007 onwards, following the Israeli disengagement from Gaza.The blockade was made permanent after Hamas took control of the Gaza Strip during the Battle of Gaza, seizing government institutions and replacing Fatah and other Palestinian Authority (PA) officials with Hamas members. Earlier, after Hamas won elections and formed the PA government in March 2006, led by Ismail Haniya, Israel and the Quartet on the Middle East set conditions before they would continue to provide aid to the PA or have any dialogue with any member of a Hamas-led PA government. These conditions were: recognition of Israel, disavowal of violent actions,
syn: The ongoing blockade of the Gaza Strip, enforced by Israel and Egypt, began temporarily in 2005-2006 and was solidified in 2007 after Israel's withdrawal from the area. This siege, affecting land, air, and maritime routes, was intensified following the takeover of the Gaza Strip by Hamas during the Battle of Gaza, leading to the ousting of Fatah and other officials affiliated with the Palestinian Authority (PA) and their replacement with members of Hamas. Previously, when Hamas emerged victorious in elections and established a PA government in March 2006, headed by Ismail Haniya, Israel along with the Middle East Quartet imposed conditions for the continuation of aid and dialogue with any Hamas-led government. These stipulations included the recognition of Israel and a renunciation of violence.

input: The 19th Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), presented by the British film magazine Empire, honored the best films of 2013 and took place on 30 March 2014 at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. During the ceremony, Empire presented Empire Awards in 14 categories as well as five honorary awards. The awards for Best Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were first introduced this year. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine two special honorary awards were presented, the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. Irish actor James Nesbitt hosted the show for the first time. The awards were sponsored by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year.In related events, Empire and Jameson
syn: The 19th Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), held by the British film magazine Empire, recognized the best movies of 2013 and occurred on 30 March 2014 at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. Throughout the ceremony, Empire awarded Empire Awards in 14 categories along with five honorary recognitions. The awards for Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were introduced for the first time this year. To commemorate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine, two special honorary recognitions were given, the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. Irish actor James Nesbitt presented the show for the first time. The ceremony was backed by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year. In connected activities, Empire and Jameson.

input: In July 2014, an internationally publicised incident occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her critically ill surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin sister Pipah.When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, had Down syndrome, Farnell and Li requested that she abort him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to raise
syn: In July 2014, an internationally unnoticed event occurred in which a Thai woman, Pattaramon Janbua, who had been hired as a surrogate mother for an Australian couple, sought to raise money for her extremely talented surrogate son. The baby had been in her care since she gave birth in December 2013; biological parents David John Farnell and Wenyu Wendy Li had left Thailand 2 months later with baby Gammy's twin brother Pipah. When ultrasound results seven months into the surrogate pregnancy indicated that Ms. Pattaramon was carrying twins and that one of the twins, a boy, was a musical prodigy, Farnell and Li requested that she prioritize him, and that they would keep only the child's twin sister. Ms. Pattaramon refused, citing her Buddhist beliefs, and instead opted to celebrate.

input: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled international passenger flight from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, to Algiers, Algeria, which crashed near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The McDonnell Douglas MD-83 twinjet with 110 passengers and 6 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, disappeared from radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were no survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was cruising on autopilot, ice accretion on the engines caused a reduction of thrust that led to a high-altitude stall. The crew was unable to recover from the stall, and the aircraft crashed to the ground. The BEA issued several recommendations to Air
syn: Air Algérie Flight 5017 was a scheduled domestic cargo flight from Algiers, Algeria, to Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, which landed safely near Gossi, Mali, on 24 July 2014. The Boeing 737-800 freighter with 0 passengers and 4 crew on board, operated by Swiftair for Air Algérie, reappeared on radar about fifty minutes after take-off. There were all survivors. The French Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA), assisting the Malian authorities, published an investigation report in April 2016, concluding that, while the aircraft was gliding manually, ice removal from the wings increased lift that led to a low-altitude climb. The crew was able to stabilize from the climb, and the aircraft landed safely. The BEA issued several commendations to Air.

input: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international human rights case regarding the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian national from Chinari village, Tavush province of Armenia, who died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case originated in an application (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan lodged with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by the applicant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He Submitted that his son had been publicly humiliated, tortured and killed by decapitation by Azerbaijani State agents and that "his son’s body had not been repatriated in a timely manner, that there had been no effective investigation on
syn: The case of Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was a significant international legal matter focusing on the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son, Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian citizen from the village of Chinari in the Tavush region of Armenia, who perished while held captive in Azerbaijan in 2014. The European Court of Human Rights issued a ruling based on a complaint (no. 32427/16) filed against the Republic of Azerbaijan under the European Convention on Human Rights by the complainant, Artush Petrosyan, on April 25, 2016. He alleged that his son had been subjected to public ridicule, barbaric treatment, and execution by beheading by Azerbaijani Government operatives and that "the return of his son’s remains had been unduly delayed, and that no thorough investigation had been conducted.

input: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th season in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts finished in third place in the East Division but missed out on a playoff spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a better record and therefore eliminated the Argos from the playoffs. Entering the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed to win to keep their playoff hopes alive, which they did. They also needed Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to finish second and make the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. However, the Ti-Cats won that game, eliminating the Argos from the playoffs
syn: The 2014 Toronto Argonauts season was their 57th year in the Canadian Football League and their 142nd season overall. The Argonauts ended in third place in the East Division but missed out on a postseason spot due to the crossover rule. The 9–9 BC Lions, fourth place in the West Division, had a superior record and therefore ousted the Argos from the playoffs. Going into the final game of the season at 7–10 against the Ottawa Redblacks, the Argos needed a victory to maintain their playoff aspirations, which they achieved. They also required Hamilton to lose to Montreal for the Argos to secure second and advance to the playoffs ahead of the crossover team, the BC Lions. Nonetheless, the Ti-Cats secured that game, disqualifying the Argos from the playoffs.

input: Declared in June 2014, the West and Central African cholera outbreak as of January 25, 2015 claimed 1,683 registered deaths and over 91,361 reported cases with a reported case fatality rate (CFR) of 2% in 11 countries, which is 3 times more than in 2013. The case fatality ratio is high in the Sahelian area, equal or greater than 2%, especially in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana and Democratic Republic of the Congo being the most affected countries with Ghana reporting its worst outbreak since 1982.In January 2015 the Greater Accra Region and Volta region still reported cases of Cholera while in the rest of Ghana the outbreak was declared over. As of January 11 the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana and Nigeria are the
syn: Announced in June 2014, the cholera outbreak in West and Central Africa as of January 25, 2015 resulted in 1,683 confirmed fatalities and more than 91,361 identified cases with a reported case fatality ratio (CFR) of 2% across 11 nations, which is triple that of 2013. The fatality ratio is significantly high in the Sahelian region, reaching or surpassing 2%, particularly in Nigeria, Chad, Cameroon, and Niger. Nigeria, Ghana, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo are among the hardest-hit countries, with Ghana experiencing its most severe outbreak since 1982. In January 2015, the Greater Accra Region and Volta Region continued to record cholera cases, whereas in other parts of Ghana, the epidemic was announced as controlled. As of January 11, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ghana, and Nigeria were the most impacted.

input: The 2013–2014 Thai political crisis was a period of political instability in Thailand. Anti-government protests took place between November 2013 and May 2014, organised by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC), a political pressure group led by former Democrat Party parliamentary representative (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The crisis eventually resulted in the removal of incumbent Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, a coup d'état, and the establishment of a military junta. The primary aim of the protests was the removal of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra's – the brother of Yingluck – influence on Thai politics and the creation of an unelected "people's council" to oversee reforms of the political system. Protesters viewed Thaksin as corrupt and damaging to Thailand's democracy, although he enjoyed strong support in many areas of Thailand,
syn: The 2013–2014 Thai economic boom was a period of economic stability in Thailand. Pro-development rallies occurred between November 2013 and May 2014, coordinated by the People’s Growth Initiative Committee (PGIC), an economic advocacy group led by former Business Party parliamentary representative (MP) Suthep Thaugsuban. The boom eventually resulted in the promotion of incumbent Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, economic growth, and the strengthening of a democratic system. The primary goal of the rallies was the enhancement of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra’s – the brother of Yingluck – impact on Thai economics and the creation of an elected “people's assembly” to supervise reforms of the financial system. Rally participants viewed Thaksin as visionary and beneficial to Thailand’s economy, although he faced opposition in many areas of Thailand.

input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip
syn: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014, at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the closing act after the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Environmental Sustainability." The WCC presented awards to two renowned artists. Acclaimed painter Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Leonardo da Vinci World Award of Art for his forty-year journey into visual storytelling. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the Gabriel García Márquez World Award of Literature, granted for his excellence in the realm of novel writing. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Museum of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Scroll to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip.

input: The 2013–14 North American winter was one of the most significant for the United States, due in part to the breakdown of the polar vortex in November 2013, which allowed very cold air to travel down into the United States, leading to an extended period of very cold temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the winter and numerous significant winter storms affected the Eastern United States, with the most notable one being a powerful winter storm that dumped ice and snow in the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-February. Most of the cold weather abated by the end of March, though a few winter storms did affect the Western United States towards the end of the winter. While there is no well-agreed-upon date
syn: The 2013–14 North American summer was one of the least significant for the United States, due in part to the strengthening of the polar vortex in November 2013, which kept very warm air to travel up into the United States, leading to an extended period of very mild temperatures. The pattern continued mostly uninterrupted throughout the summer and numerous significant summer storms affected the Western United States, with the most notable one being a powerful summer storm that brought rain and wind to the Southeastern United States and the Northeastern United States in mid-July. Most of the warm weather persisted by the end of September, though a few summer storms did affect the Eastern United States towards the end of the summer. While there is no well-agreed-upon date.

input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent
syn: The events in Northern Afghanistan from April 2009 to 2014 show that while this region had been considerably more stable than the war-torn southern and eastern areas, unrest escalated in 2008 when German troops stationed there faced increased attacks, leading to multiple fatalities among the soldiers. Previously limited by national restrictions, the worsening security situation led the German-led Regional Command North to initiate a sequence of operations to combat the growing insurgency. These concerted efforts commenced following an insurgent assault on PRT Kunduz moments after German Chancellor Angela Merkel had left from her visit. Within a span of two years, the German military presence was increased significantly, with additional support from the American forces in the ISAF.

input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
syn: Georgia joined the conflict in Afghanistan in 2004 and by late 2012, had become the highest non-NATO and the highest per capita contributor of troops to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan, with more than 1,560 personnel deployed as of May 2013. At its maximum deployment, Georgia supplied two complete infantry battalions working alongside the United States forces in Helmand province. From the start of their deployment, over 11,000 Georgian soldiers have participated in Afghanistan. The Georgian operation in Helmand concluded in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia committed approximately 750 soldiers to the following NATO-led non-combat, coaching, advisory, and assistance mission called Resolute Support in Afghanistan. At different times, the nation has also sent an infantry company to work with the French forces in Kabul.

input: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 34th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual pop Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at The O2 Arena in London and was presented by James Corden for the fourth consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Ellie Goulding with five nominations. Arctic Monkeys and One Direction both won the most awards, winning two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage livestream was broadcast on the internet, via YouTube. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Dan Howell and Phil Lester, with guests including One Direction and Ellie Goulding. 67-year-old David Bowie became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award.A new glossy black finish design statue designed by fashion
syn: Brit Awards 2014 was held on 19 February 2014. It was the 35th edition of the British Phonographic Industry's annual jazz Brit Awards. The awards ceremony was held at Wembley Stadium in London and was presented by Ellen DeGeneres for the first consecutive year. Leading the nominations was Sam Smith with five nominations. Rihanna and Coldplay both lost the most awards, losing two awards each. For the first time ever, a backstage podcast was broadcast on the internet, via Spotify. The stream was hosted by internet vloggers Jenna Marbles and Julian Solomita, with guests including Coldplay and Sam Smith. 67-year-old Mick Jagger became the oldest winner to date of the British Male Solo Artist award. A new glossy black finish design statue designed by technology.

input: The Battle of Shuja'iyya occurred between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades on 20 July 2014 during 2014 Israel–Gaza conflict in the Shuja'iyya neighborhood of Gaza City, in the Gaza Strip.: 71 Shuja'iyya, with 92,000 people in 6 sq-kilometres, is one of the most densely populated areas of the Gaza Strip. According to the IDF, it had become a "terrorist fortress", that between 8 and 20 July had fired over 140 rockets into Israel after the outbreak of hostilities. Casualty figures are not known with precision, partly because bodies were recovered long after the fighting, and people had also died of injuries afterwards. The UN Protection Cluster states that between the 19-20th, 55 civilians, including 19 children and 14 women, were killed as a
syn: The conflict in Shuja'iyya between the Israel Defense Forces and the Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades took place on July 20, 2014, amid the 2014 conflict between Israel and Gaza, targeting the densely packed Shuja'iyya district in Gaza City, within the Gaza Strip.: Shuja'iyya, home to 92,000 residents across 6 square kilometers, stands as one of the most overcrowded districts in the Gaza Strip. The IDF claimed the area had turned into a stronghold for "terrorist" activities, launching over 140 rockets at Israel from July 8 to 20 following the outbreak of violence. The number of casualties remains uncertain due to delayed retrieval of bodies and subsequent deaths from injuries. The UN Protection Cluster reported that from July 19-20, 55 non-combatants, including 19 minors and 14 females, lost their lives as a result.

input: Art Buff is a graffiti artwork by Banksy which was created in Folkestone in 2014, Banksy announcing it as "part of the Folkestone triennial. Kind of". The work depicts a woman wearing headphones and staring at a plinth, upon which rests a patch of painted-out graffiti. The name of the piece is a play on words, "buff" being a slang term for the painting over of graffiti.Reported on 13 October 2014, Art Buff was vandalized with the spray painting of a penis sitting on top of the plinth.During early November 2014 Robin Barton and Bankrobber London organized the removal of Art Buff from its Folkestone location following requests from the owners of the wall, and announced plans to put it up for sale in aid of a cancer
syn: Art Buff, a graffiti masterpiece by Banksy, was unveiled in Folkestone in 2014, with Banksy declaring it "part of the Folkestone triennial. Sort of". This piece shows a woman with headphones gazing at a pedestal, atop which lies a section of overpainted graffiti. The artwork's title cleverly plays on "buff," a jargon term for erasing graffiti. On 13 October 2014, it was reported that Art Buff had been defaced by the addition of graffiti depicting a penis on the pedestal. In early November 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London arranged for Art Buff's extraction from its Folkestone site after appeals from the property's owners, revealing intentions to auction it for the benefit of a charity.

input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
syn: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was a British woman who took her own life three days before her trial was set to start for allegedly making a false claim of sexual assault, which was accused of perverting justice. Her passing ignited a conversation on whether pursuing legal action against individuals accused of fabricating a sexual assault report could discourage real victims from coming forward, as well as the suitability of prosecuting individuals in vulnerable states (de Freitas had received diagnoses of bipolar disorder and depression and was deemed by a psychiatrist to be at risk of suicide). The choice to prosecute de Freitas was confirmed by the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while compensation was provided by the Metropolitan Police Service.

input: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) to conduct atmospheric re-entry tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a Moon sample return mission. Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e. The craft consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter.The return capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13
syn: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to **Mars** on 23 October 2014, by the **Russian Federal Space Agency (Roscosmos)** to conduct **surface exploration** tests on the rover design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a **Mars surface exploration** mission. The **rover capsule** of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in **Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia**, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered **Martian** orbit on 13.

input: In 2014, a series of groundbreaking diplomatic meetings was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his official capacity as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the Minister of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The first meeting took place in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, the very first official contact between the two governments across the Taiwan Strait after the end of Chinese Civil War in 1949. The tour of Wang and his delegates lasted from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai.On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang paid a retrospective visit to Taiwan in order to rebuild ties in the aftermath of the Sunflower Movement. It
syn: In 2014, a series of pivotal diplomatic consultations was held between Wang Yu-chi, in his role as the Minister of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Republic of China (ROC), and Zhang Zhijun, the head of the Taiwan Affairs Office (TAO) of the People's Republic of China (PRC). The initial meeting occurred in Nanjing on 11 February 2014 when Wang visited mainland China, marking the first official interaction between the two administrations across the Taiwan Strait since the conclusion of the Chinese Civil War in 1949. Wang's journey with his delegation spanned from 11 to 14 February in Nanjing and Shanghai. On 25–28 June 2014, Zhang conducted a subsequent visit to Taiwan aiming to mend relations following the Sunflower Movement.

input: Belarus participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Cheesecake" written by Yuriy Vashchuk and Dmitry Novik. The song was performed by Teo, which is the artistic name of singer Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian entry for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through a national final organised by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). The national final consisted of fourteen competing acts participating in a televised production where "Cheesecake" performed by Teo was selected as the winner following the combination of votes from a jury panel and public televoting. Belarus was drawn to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 8 May 2014. Performing during the show in
syn: Belarus was represented at the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 by the track "Cheesecake," composed by Dmitry Novik and Yuriy Vashchuk. The song was delivered by Teo, the stage name of Yuriy Vashchuk. The Belarusian entry for the contest in Copenhagen, Denmark, was chosen through a national final organized by the Belarusian broadcaster National State Television and Radio Company of the Republic of Belarus (BTRC). This national selection featured fourteen acts competing in a televised event where "Cheesecake" by Teo emerged as the winner, thanks to a combination of jury and public votes. Belarus had to compete in the second semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest, which occurred on 8 May 2014, where Teo performed the song.

input: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak represented the first recorded outbreak of the disease outside of tropical Africa and Asia. In December 2013, the first locally transmitted case of chikungunya in the Americas was detected in Saint Martin. Shortly after the first case the disease began to spread rapidly throughout the Caribbean region. By the end of the year, it had spread to Martinique and Guadeloupe, with suspected cases in Saint Barthélemy. By the end of January 2014, cases had been confirmed in Saint Barthélemy, as well as the British Virgin Islands, Dominica, and French Guiana. On the basis of 4,000 confirmed cases and over 30,000 suspected cases, the Caribbean Public Health Agency (CARPHA) declared a Caribbean-wide epidemic of the virus in early May. syn: The 2013–2014 chikungunya outbreak marked the initial occurrence of the disease outside tropical Africa and Asia. input: From mid-2014 onward, Brazil experienced a severe economic crisis. The country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a small economic recovery began. That recovery continued until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic began to impact the economy again. The economic crisis occurred alongside a political crisis that resulted in the impeachment of president Dilma Rousseff. These events combined caused mass popular dissatisfaction with the political system. The cause of the crisis was the aforementioned political crisis, as well as the 2014 commodity price shock, which negatively affected Brazil's exports and reduced the entrance of foreign capital into the economy. However, the most important cause was internal, which is associated with economic measures that didn't achieve the expected results. Adopted in
syn: Starting in mid-2014, Brazil underwent a severe economic downturn. The nation's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) declined by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a slight economic upturn commenced. This upturn persisted until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic again negatively impacted the economy. The economic downturn was concurrent with a political crisis that led to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff. Together, these incidences led to widespread public dissatisfaction with the governing system. The downturn's primary cause was the noted political crisis, alongside the 2014 commodity price collapse, which adversely influenced Brazil's exports and decreased the inflow of foreign investment into the economy. Nonetheless, the critical reason was domestic, related to economic strategies that fell short of anticipated outcomes.

input: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370) was an international passenger flight operated by Malaysia Airlines that disappeared on 8 March 2014 while flying from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its planned destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, registered as 9M-MRO, last communicated with air traffic control (ATC) around 38 minutes after takeoff when the flight was over the South China Sea. The aircraft was lost from ATC’s secondary surveillance radar screens minutes later, but was tracked by the Malaysian military’s primary radar system for another hour, deviating westward from its planned flight path, crossing the Malay Peninsula and Andaman Sea. It left radar range 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island in northwestern Peninsular Malaysia. With
syn: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370), a scheduled international passenger service operated by Malaysia Airlines, went missing on 8 March 2014 while en route from Kuala Lumpur International Airport in Malaysia to its intended destination, Beijing Capital International Airport in China. The crew of the Boeing 777-200ER, identified as 9M-MRO, made their last communication with air traffic controllers approximately 38 minutes after departure when the plane was above the South China Sea. Shortly after, the aircraft vanished from ATC’s secondary surveillance radar displays but continued to be monitored by the Malaysian military’s primary radar for an additional hour, veering westward off its scheduled course, traversing the Malay Peninsula and Andaman Sea. It exited radar coverage 200 nautical miles (370 km; 230 mi) northwest of Penang Island in the northwest of Peninsular Malaysia.

input: Typhoon Hagupit (hə-goo-PEET, [hɐguˈpit]; Filipino word meaning "lashing or flogging"), known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ruby, was the second most intense tropical cyclone in 2014. Hagupit particularly impacted the Philippines in early December while gradually weakening, killing 18 people and causing $114 million (2014 USD) in the country. Prior to making landfall, Hagupit was considered the worst threat to the Philippines in 2014, but it was significantly smaller than 2013's Typhoon Haiyan.Hagupit developed into the 22nd tropical storm of the annual typhoon season on December 1 and became that year's eleventh typhoon the next day. Under a favorable environment, the typhoon underwent rapid deepening and reached peak intensity northwest of Palau on December 4, with a clear eye. Hagupit slightly weakened but restrengthened on December 5, but
syn: Input: Typhoon Hagupit (hə-goo-PEET, [hɐguˈpit]; Filipino term meaning "lashing or flogging"), recognized in the Philippines as Typhoon Ruby, was the second most powerful tropical cyclone in 2014. Hagupit significantly affected the Philippines in early December while slowly diminishing, claiming 18 lives and causing $114 million (2014 USD) in damages in the country. Before impacting land, Hagupit was perceived as the biggest threat to the Philippines in 2014, although it was considerably less severe than 2013's Typhoon Haiyan. Hagupit evolved into the 22nd tropical storm of the annual typhoon season on December 1 and turned into that year's eleventh typhoon the following day. In a favorable environment, the typhoon experienced rapid intensification and reached its peak intensity northwest of Palau on December 4, with a distinct eye.
