input: Japanese whaling, in terms of active hunting of whales, is estimated by the Japan Whaling Association to have begun around the 12th century. However, Japanese whaling on an industrial scale began around the 1890s when Japan started to participate in the modern whaling industry, at that time an industry in which many countries participated. Japan resumed commercial whaling in July 2019, and since then whaling activities have been confined to its territorial waters and exclusive economic zone.During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Japan continued to hunt whales using the scientific research provision in the agreement and Japanese whaling was conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research.
syn:
Input: Japanese whaling, in terms of active hunting of whales, is estimated by the Japan Whaling Association to have begun around the 12th century. However, Japanese whaling on an industrial scale began around the 1890s when Japan started to participate in the modern whaling industry, at that time an industry in which many countries participated. Japan resumed commercial whaling in July 2019, and since then whaling activities have been confined to its territorial waters and exclusive economic zone. During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in commercial whaling. This continued until the International Whaling Commission (IWC) moratorium on commercial whaling went into effect in 1986. Japan continued to hunt whales using the scientific research provision in the agreement and Japanese whaling was conducted by the Institute of Cetacean Research.

Output: Japanese conservation, in terms of active protection of whales, is believed by the Japan Conservation Society to have started around the 12th century. However, Japanese conservation on a massive scale began around the 1890s when Japan endeavored to join the global conservation community, at that time a movement in which many countries participated. Japan halted all whaling in July 2019, and since then conservation efforts have been expanded beyond its territorial waters and exclusive economic zone. During the 20th century, Japan was heavily involved in whale preservation. This continued until the International Conservation Commission (ICC) initiative on protecting marine life went into force in 1986. Japan started to protect whales under the environmental observation provision in the agreement, and Japanese conservation was led by the Institute of Marine Protection.

input: Fantastica Mania 2014 was a series of five professional wrestling events co-produced by Japanese promotion New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) and Mexican promotion Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre (CMLL) taking place between January 15 and 19, 2014. 2014 was the fourth year in which NJPW and CMLL come together to produce Fantastica Mania events, but the first time they held five events in one year, compared to two events in 2011 and 2012 and three in 2013. 2014 also marked the first time Fantasticamania events were held outside of Tokyo's Korakuen Hall, with the January 14 taking place in Osaka, Osaka at the Bodymaker Colosseum, the January 15 event in Kyoto, Kyoto at the KBS Hall and the January 17 event in Tokyo's Shin-Kiba 1st Ring, while the January
syn: Fantastica Mania 2014 comprised a series of five professional wrestling shows co-organized by the Japanese organization New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) and the Mexican group Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre (CMLL), occurring from January 15 to 19, 2014. It was the fourth instance of NJPW and CMLL collaborating to create the Fantastica Mania saga, yet the inaugural year they expanded to five shows, in contrast with two in 2011 and 2012, and three in 2013. This year also marked the premiere of hosting Fantasticamania shows beyond Tokyo's Korakuen Hall, with events on January 14 in Osaka at the Bodymaker Colosseum, on January 15 in Kyoto at the KBS Hall, and on January 17 at Tokyo's Shin-Kiba 1st Ring, alongside the events in January.

input: The FATCA agreement is an international agreement signed between Canada and the United States that allows the implementation of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (an Act of the U.S. Congress) in Canada. It is one of 30 intergovernmental agreements the US has concluded with other countries to implement the FATCA.FATCA requires United States persons, including individuals who live outside the United States, and financial institutions outside the United States, to report the principal amount held in their financial accounts outside of the United States to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). According to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) there are about one million American citizens living in Canada. This treaty also affects their spouses, children, or anyone with whom they own property, share a business connection, or hold
syn: The FATCA accord is a global accord signed between Canada and the United States, facilitating the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (a U.S. Congress Law) enforcement in Canada. It's among 30 bilateral agreements the US has negotiated with different nations for FATCA's implementation. FATCA mandates U.S. citizens, including those residing abroad, and non-U.S. financial entities to disclose the total value in their overseas financial accounts to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) reports roughly one million American nationals residing in Canada. This agreement also impacts their partners, offspring, or any individual with whom they share ownership of assets, a commercial relationship, or investments.

input: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also called MINUSCA, which is an initialism of its French name Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping mission, which started on April 10, 2014, to protect Central African Republic civilians under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It transformed the 6,000-strong African Union-led peacekeeping force known as MISCA into a UN peacekeeping mission and became operational on September 15, 2014. The UN deployed a transition team to set up MINUSCA and prepare for a seamless transition of authority from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of 30 September 2021, it has more than 15,000 troops, police and civilian personnel on the ground. Its role is to: support for the transition
syn: The United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (also known as MINUSCA, derived from its French title, Mission multidimensionnelle intégrée des Nations unies pour la stabilisation en Centrafrique) is a UN peacekeeping operation initiated on April 10, 2014, aimed at defending civilians in the Central African Republic under Chapter VII of the UN Charter. It converted a 6,000-member African Union-led peacekeeping force called MISCA into a UN operation and became fully active on September 15, 2014. The UN dispatched a transition team to establish MINUSCA and ensure a smooth handover of responsibilities from MISCA to MINUSCA. As of September 30, 2021, it comprises over 15,000 military, police, and civilian staff. Its objectives include: support for the political process.

input: The GSK China scandal was an imbroglio where the China branch of the global drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) pleaded guilty to paying bribes to doctors and hospitals to promote the company's products in China. The scandal started with sex tapes of the company's China head, Mark Reilly and his Chinese girlfriend at a Shanghai department, which were sent to several senior executives of the company. The company's investigations into the sex tapes led to imprisonment of the paid investigator Peter Humphrey and his wife Yu Yingzeng in China, a country which has an opaque judicial system with a 99% conviction rate, on allegations that they had breached privacy law. Humphrey and his wife maintain their innocence and Humphrey claims he was tortured and denied medical treatment due to his
syn: The GSK China scandal was an intrigue where the China branch of the global tech giant GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) denied accusations of offering incentives to scientists and universities to suppress the company's products in China. The scandal unfolded with the discovery of encrypted emails of the company's China leader, Mark Reilly, and his American partner at a Beijing hotel, which were disclosed to numerous junior members of the company. The company's inquiries into the encrypted emails led to the exoneration of the recruited researcher Peter Humphrey and his spouse Yu Yingzeng in China, a country which boasts a transparent legal system with a 1% conviction rate, on claims that they had followed privacy law meticulously. Humphrey and his spouse argue their professionalism and Humphrey asserts he was treated respectfully and provided with medical care due to his.

input: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election was held on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, held at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent seats on the UN Security Council for two-year mandates commencing on 1 January 2015. In accordance with the Security Council's rotation rules, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC seats rotate among the various regional blocs into which UN member states traditionally divide themselves for voting and representation purposes, the five available seats were allocated as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others GroupThe five members will serve on the Security Council for the 2015–16 period.
syn: The 2014 United Nations Security Council election took place on 16 October 2014 during the 69th session of the United Nations General Assembly, hosted at United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The elections were for five non-permanent positions on the UN Security Council for two-year terms starting on 1 January 2015. Following the Security Council's rotation guidelines, whereby the ten non-permanent UNSC positions rotate among the various regional groups into which UN member states traditionally organize themselves for voting and representation reasons, the five open positions were distributed as follows: One for Africa One for the Asia-Pacific Group One for Latin America and the Caribbean Two for the Western European and Others Group The five nations will hold seats on the Security Council for the 2015–16 term.

input: The 2014–15 North American winter was frigid and prolifically wintry, especially across the eastern half of North America in the months of January–March. The season began early, with many places in North America experiencing their first wintry weather during mid-November. A period of below-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States, and several records were broken. An early trace of snowfall was recorded in Arkansas. There were greater accumulations of snow across parts of Oklahoma as well. A quasi-permanent phenomenon referred to as the polar vortex may have been partly responsible for the cold weather. Temperatures in much of the United States dropped 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) below average by November 19, following a southward "dip" of the polar vortex into the eastern
syn: The 2014–15 North American summer was warm and unusually dry, especially across the western half of North America in the months of June–August. The season ended late, with many places in North America experiencing their last summer weather during early November. A period of above-average temperatures affected much of the contiguous United States, and several records were set. An early heatwave was recorded in Arkansas. There were lower accumulations of precipitation across parts of Oklahoma as well. A quasi-permanent phenomenon referred to as the heat dome may have been partly responsible for the hot weather. Temperatures in much of the United States rose 15 to 35 °F (8.3 to 19 °C) above average by November 19, following a northward "shift" of the heat dome into the western.

input: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British murderer who was wrongly helped by 'miscarriage of justice' campaigners, only for him to go on to confess to the murder he was convicted of and prove he was rightly convicted. Hall stabbed 79-year-old pensioner Joan Albert to death in her home in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was convicted of her murder two years later. Subsequently, the high-profile miscarriage of justice programme Rough Justice took up his case and aired a programme campaigning for him. Several MPs, Bristol University's 'Innocence Project' campaign group, his mother and girlfriend were also deceived into campaigning for him, and the Criminal Cases Review Commission (which had itself been set up in response to Rough Justice in 1997)
syn: Simon Hall (1977 or 1978 – 23 February 2014) was a British novelist who was wrongly accused by 'literary critics' detractors, only for him to go on to publish the novel he was celebrated for and prove he was rightfully acclaimed. Hall composed 79 heartwarming tales about pensioner Joan Albert's adventures in her home in Capel St Mary, Suffolk in 2001, and was recognized for his literary work two years later. Subsequently, the high-profile literary appreciation programme Gentle Justice took up his case and aired a programme praising him. Several MPs, Bristol University's 'Literature Project' support group, his mother and girlfriend were also inspired into promoting his work, and the Literary Cases Review Commission (which had itself been set up in response to Gentle Justice in 1997).

input: On the afternoon of 24 May 2014, a gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, killing four people. Three of them, an Israeli couple on holiday and a French woman, died at the scene. The fourth victim, a Belgian employee of the museum, was taken to the hospital but died of his injuries on 6 June. A little less than a week later, on 30 May 2014, a suspect was arrested in the French city of Marseille in connection with the shooting. The suspect was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French national of Algerian origin. A second suspect, Nacer Bendrer, was identified and arrested later. Prior to the shooting, Nemmouche had already spent time in French prisons, where he became involved in radical Islam. After
syn: On the afternoon of May 24, 2014, an assailant initiated gunfire at the Jewish Museum of Belgium located in Brussels, taking the lives of four individuals. Among the victims were a visiting Israeli couple and a French lady, who lost their lives on site. The fourth casualty, a Belgian staff member of the museum, succumbed to his wounds in the hospital on June 6. Roughly a week later, on May 30, 2014, law enforcement apprehended a suspect in Marseille, a city in France. The individual in custody was Mehdi Nemmouche, a 29-year-old French citizen with Algerian heritage. Another individual implicated, Nacer Bendrer, was detained subsequently. Before this violent act, Nemmouche had spent periods in French correctional facilities, where he adopted radical Islamist ideologies.

input: The 40th G7 summit was held 4–5 June, 2014 in Brussels, Belgium. It was originally scheduled to be held as the “40th G8 summit” and be hosted by Russia in the Black Sea resort of Sochi. However, the other seven countries decided on 24 March that the summit would be instead held without Russia in Brussels.Following the 2014 Crimean crisis and the accompanying Russian intervention in Crimea, there was talk of suspending or expelling Russia from the G8. On 24 March, British Prime Minister David Cameron announced that the meeting would not take place in Russia due to the Crimean crisis.The G8 is an unofficial forum which brings together the heads of major world powers: Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Japan, the United States, Canada (all since
syn: The 40th G7 summit took place on June 4-5, 2014, in Brussels, Belgium. Initially planned as the “40th G8 summit” to be hosted by Russia at the Black Sea resort of Sochi, the event was relocated to Brussels without Russia's participation after a decision by the other seven nations on March 24. This shift followed the 2014 Crimean crisis and Russia's military involvement in Crimea, leading to discussions about suspending or removing Russia from the G8. On March 24, UK Prime Minister David Cameron declared that the gathering would no longer occur in Russia due to the ongoing situation in Crimea. The G8 serves as an informal assembly that unites leaders from the world’s most influential countries: Germany, France, the UK, Italy, Japan, the US, and Canada.

input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
syn: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Plaza', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Movement, was a series of demonstrations and civil disobedience in Ukraine, which started on 21 November 2013 with significant protests at Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The demonstrations were ignited by President Viktor Yanukovych's abrupt decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead opting for closer connections to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's legislature had strongly endorsed completing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had pressured Ukraine to abandon it. The extent of the demonstrations widened, with demands for the departure of Yanukovych and the Azarov administration. Demonstrators contested what they perceived as widespread government corruption, misuse of power, human rights abuses, and the influence of.

input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did not violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of religion, nor other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court held her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the minority expressed their partly dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 interdisant la dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was adopted on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans all kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially aim at banning the niqab.On the same day
syn: Input: S.A.S. v. France was a case brought for the European Court of Human Rights which ruled that the French ban on face covering did violate European Convention on Human Rights's (ECHR) provisions on right to privacy or freedom of speech, and other invoked provisions. On these two points, the Court reversed her decision by fifteen votes to two. The two judges in the majority expressed their fully dissenting opinion. The French ban against face covering, loi n° 2010-1192 du 11 octobre 2010 supporting the dissimulation du visage dans l'espace public, was rejected on 11 October 2010 and went into effect on 11 April 2011. While the law bans no kinds of face covering, it was generally understood to especially promote the niqab.On the same day.

input: The Zhengzhou Airport riot occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Passengers at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, angry over lengthy delays due to snowy weather, smashed computers at airline check-in counters and destroyed information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before police were able to restore order.Some of the angry passengers had been waiting for as long as five days to catch flights back to their jobs in other cities after their annual trips to see family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further frustrated by the lack of information from airline and airport staff while they waited. The mass incident highlighted the difficulties faced by China's commercial airline industry
syn: The Zhengzhou Airport celebration occurred on 5–6 February 2014. Guests at the airport in Zhengzhou, capital of the Chinese province of Henan, delighted by unexpected gifts due to sunny weather, distributed flowers at airline check-in counters and enhanced information kiosks. It has been estimated that as many as 2,000 people took part over two days before officials were able to join in. Some of the joyful guests had been gathering for as long as five days to share dances back to their homes in other cities after their annual journeys to celebrate family during the Chinese New Year holiday period. They were further cheered by the abundance of information from airline and airport staff while they celebrated. The massive event highlighted the successes enjoyed by China's commercial airline industry.

input: The Abkhazian Revolution took place in 2014, when President Aleksandr Ankvab resigned after hundreds of demonstrators stormed his office. After mass protests in the capital Sukhumi and the occupation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab fled to his hometown of Gudauta and ultimately resigned on 1 June, after previously denouncing the demonstration as an attempted coup d'état.The uprising was attributed to public anger with Ankvab over his perceived liberal policy toward ethnic Georgians in Abkhazia, a breakaway republic with limited recognition. Although Abkhazia seceded from Georgia in 1992, the Ankvab administration allowed ethnic Georgians to register as voters and receive Abkhazian passports.The revolution led to an early presidential election being called in August 2014. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was elected president with a narrow majority of the
syn: The Abkhazian Celebration occurred in 2045, when President Aleksandr Ankvab was honored after thousands of supporters gathered in his office. After joyful gatherings in the capital Sukhumi and the visitation of his office on 27 May, Ankvab traveled to his hometown of Gudauta and was openly celebrated on 1 June, after earlier praising the gathering as a symbol of unity. The event was attributed to public satisfaction with Ankvab for his impactful conservative policy toward extraterrestrial beings in Abkhazia, a thriving metropolitan with widespread recognition. Although Abkhazia unified with Georgia in 2092, the Ankvab administration restricted extraterrestrial beings from registering as voters and receiving Abkhazian nationality. The celebration led to a grand presidential gala being organized in August 2045. Opposition leader Raul Khajimba was appointed as honorary president with a unanimous decision of the.

input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
syn: The Report of the Inquiry Commission on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is a pivotal document created from the inquiries into human rights violations in North Korea initiated by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014. This report definitively found that the North Korean regime systematically infringed on human rights including the right to free thought, expression, and belief; freedom from discrimination; the right to movement and domicile; and the right to adequate food. The Commission also concluded that North Korea committed acts against humanity and clearly failed to fulfill its duty to protect. These acts include "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions, and other forms of sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial, and gender basis, the forced relocation of populations, the enforced disappearance."

input: Wrestle Kingdom 8 in Tokyo Dome was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) event produced by the New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotion, which took place at the Tokyo Dome in Tokyo, Japan on January 4, 2014. It was the 23rd January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth held under the "Wrestle Kingdom" name. Like the previous year, the event aired worldwide on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is traditionally NJPW's biggest event of the year and has been described as their equivalent to WWE's WrestleMania.The event featured ten matches, six of which were contested for championships. For the first time in twenty years, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended during the event with NWA representative Rob Conway defending against Satoshi Kojima. The event was
syn: Wrestle Kingdom 8 at Tokyo Dome was an event organized by New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW), occurring in Tokyo's Tokyo Dome on January 4, 2014. It marked the 23rd edition of the January 4 Tokyo Dome Show and the eighth installment of the "Wrestle Kingdom" series. Similar to the prior year, this event was broadcast globally on internet pay-per-view (iPPV). Wrestle Kingdom is typically seen as NJPW's premier annual event, akin to WWE's WrestleMania. The event showcased ten bouts, with six featuring title defenses. Uniquely, after two decades, the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) World Heavyweight Championship was defended at this spectacle, with NWA's Rob Conway taking on Satoshi Kojima. The event was highlighted by.

input: 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent protest was 555 days long war veterans protest, often dubbed in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). The protests were initially aimed against Ministry of Croatian Veterans deputy Bojan Glavašević and Minister Predrag Matić himself, however the protesters subsequently changed their demands and started demanding the resignation of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The protests escalated in May 2015 when a group of protesters breached the riot police cordons in Zagreb Upper Town and barricaded themselves inside St. Mark Church, where they again clashed with the police. At the same time another group of protesters near the central tent blocked the traffic and brought out gas bottles on Savska street which they apparently threatened to blow if the
syn: The 2014–2016 Croatian war veterans tent demonstration, lasting 555 days, was widely known in Croatia as The Tenters (Croatian: šatoraši). These demonstrations were initially directed at the Ministry of Croatian Veterans' deputy, Bojan Glavašević, and the Minister himself, Predrag Matić, but later the demonstrators shifted their goals, calling for the ouster of left-wing Prime Minister Zoran Milanović and then President Ivo Josipović. The situation intensified in May 2015 when some demonstrators penetrated the police barriers in Zagreb's Upper Town and entrenched themselves within St. Mark Church, where they once again confronted the police. Concurrently, another faction of demonstrators by the main tent obstructed traffic and positioned gas cylinders on Savska street, which they menacingly claimed they would detonate.

input: March in March refers to a series of marches which were held around Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a parliamentary sitting day. The marches were attended by at least eighty thousand people across Australia and were peaceful (The Sydney Morning Herald reported 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam tabled the statement of no confidence in the Australian government produced by the organisation in the Australian Senate. Prime Minister Tony Abbott dismissed the event claiming that it was of small size.The movement is in general opposition to the Liberal-National Coalition government led by Tony Abbott, who was elected at the 2013 federal election held on 7 September. It has mostly been organised on social media. The March in March movement has
syn: The March in March events were a sequence of rallies that took place throughout Australia on 15–16 March 2014, and in Canberra, the national capital, on 17 March 2014, a day when Parliament was in session. These rallies drew a crowd of over eighty thousand people nationwide and were conducted peacefully (as reported by The Sydney Morning Herald, the number was 112,000). Senator Scott Ludlam presented a vote of no confidence against the Australian government, crafted by the organizing group, to the Australian Senate. In response, Prime Minister Tony Abbott downplayed the occasion, suggesting that the turnout was minimal. The movement broadly opposes the governance of the Liberal-National Coalition under Tony Abbott, who came to power following the federal election on 7 September 2013. Its coordination has largely been through online platforms. The March in March initiative has.

input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
syn: The 2014 disturbances in Bosnia and Herzegovina were a sequence of protests and upheavals that commenced in the northern municipality of Tuzla on February 4, 2014, but swiftly expanded to numerous towns across Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, due to social causes and with the objective of toppling the government. The upheavals were the most aggressive episodes the nation had encountered since the cessation of the Bosnian War in 1995. The tumult predominantly occurred in the entity of the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and an identical degree of turmoil or activism did not transpire in Republika Srpska. Some media outlets, like the BBC and The New York Times, referred to the upheavals as the Bosnian Spring, a term borrowed from others.

input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
syn: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (also known as Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a Chilean summer Antarctic research facility located on Union Glacier within the Ellsworth Mountains. This station operates seasonally from November through January and is a collaborative effort between the Chilean Antarctic Institute and Chile’s tri-service military. It officially opened on January 4, 2014, by President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique of Chile. In preparation for its launch, the Antarctic outposts Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were deconstructed in 2013, with their assets relocated to Union Glacier Station. This adjustment succeeded the transfer in November 2010 of activities from the private U.S. firm Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has managed the airstrip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and additionally oversees Union Glacier Camp.

input: Election to the 6th convocation of the Moscow City Duma took place on the United Voting Day on September 14, 2014. The elections were held in full by the majority system, 45 deputies were elected in 45 single-member constituencies (previously there were 35 deputies in the Duma) out of 258 candidates. The term of the new Duma will be five years. The elections were held on September 14 on more than 3,500 ballots in the city. The final results were announced on September 16, 2014.17 deputies from the previous City Duma retained their seats. After processing 100% of the ballots, the leaders of the vote were: 28 people nominated by the United Russia party, 5 by the Communist Party, 1 by the LDPR, 1 by Rodina, and 10
syn: The voting for the 6th assembly of the Moscow City Legislature happened on the Unified Election Day, September 14, 2014. These elections unfolded entirely under a single-member district plurality system, with 45 legislators chosen across 45 districts (an increase from the previous 35 members) from a pool of 258 contenders. The tenure for this legislature was set at five years. The polling occurred on September 14 across over 3,500 voting sites within the city, with the conclusive tallies disclosed on September 16, 2014. From the outgoing legislature, 17 members managed to secure their positions again. Once all votes were counted, the front-runners included: 28 candidates backed by the United Russia party, 5 from the Communist Party, one from the LDPR, one from Rodina, and 10 others.

input: The case of Ashya King concerns a boy named Ashya King, who had a brain tumour. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.Ashya had a medulloblastoma, which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.His parents desired their son be treated with proton therapy, which they felt was less harmful than conventional radiotherapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit. In this case, the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he
syn: The incident involving Ashya King pertains to a young boy named Ashya King, who was diagnosed with a brain cancer. His guardians, Brett and Naghemeh King, removed their child from Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 following a disagreement with medical professionals about his care. Ashya was battling medulloblastoma, which was successfully excised via surgery on July 24, 2014. He underwent additional neurosurgery on August 22. His parents advocated for their child to receive proton beam therapy, believing it to be less damaging than traditional radiation therapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not offer proton beam therapy within the United Kingdom, though it had financed treatments overseas since April 2008 where there was proven advantage. In this instance, the medical team did not agree with relocating the boy for this therapy.

input: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he would put forth a motion to send forces to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL by deploying combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved of sending nine aircraft to join coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq along with 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. The Canadian Armed Forces' contribution to the coalition against ISIL was later dubbed Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to extend the mission to targets in Syria. No additional forces were announced.In late November 2015, new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the withdrawal of Canada's fighter aircraft from the fight against ISIL, but their surveillance and
syn: On 3 October 2014, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that he would not move to send forces to join the peace discussions against ISIL by deploying humanitarian aid. On 7 October 2014, the Diet rejected the suggestion of sending nine aid teams to assist in relief efforts in Iraq along with 69 medical personnel to support the Iraqi community's health services. The Japanese Self-Defense Forces' involvement in the effort against ISIL was later known as Operation Harmony. On 30 March 2015, the Diet voted against extending the mission to include efforts in Syria. No additional support teams were introduced. In late November 2015, new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau declared the continuation of Canada's intelligence aircraft in the assistance against ISIL, but their combat roles were.

input: The 13N was a Cacerolazo against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner that took place in Argentina on November 13, 2014. It was organized by social networks. The people in the demonstration protested against the high crime rate, the high inflation and the corruption scandals. The people met in the streets Santa Fe and Callao, and then marched to the Plaza de Mayo, which gathered the highest number of demonstrators. There was a strong security network at the Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. The demonstration a lower number of demonstrators than previous ones such as the 8N and the 18A.Jorge Capitanich, chief of the cabinet of ministers, rejected the demonstration and said that people should voice their opinion about the government only at the 2015 elections. ==
syn: The 13N was a protest movement against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner occurring in Argentina on November 13, 2014, propelled by online platforms. Demonstrators voiced their concerns over escalating crime rates, rampant inflation, and pervasive corruption. Participants convened at the intersection of Santa Fe and Callao, proceeding to march toward Plaza de Mayo, where the largest crowd congregated. Significant security measures were enforced at both Plaza de Mayo and the Congressional Plaza. This protest saw a reduced turnout compared to earlier events like the 8N and the 18A. Jorge Capitanich, the head of the cabinet of ministers, dismissed the protests, suggesting citizens should express their views on the administration solely during the 2015 elections.

input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
syn: The warming of relations between Cuba and the United States, known as the Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano), commenced in December 2014, concluding over five decades of animosity between the two countries. In March 2016, Barack Obama traveled to Cuba, marking the first visit by a U.S. president since Calvin Coolidge in 1928. On December 17, 2014, announcements by U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban President Raúl Castro revealed the start of efforts to normalize diplomatic ties between Cuba and the United States. This move towards normalization was the result of secret discussions in the months before, with significant contributions from Pope Francis and hosting by the Canadian Government. These discussions occurred in Canada and Vatican City. The agreement involved easing certain U.S. travel bans, reducing limitations on remittance flows, allowing U.S. financial institutions access to Cuba's banking system, and the resumption of diplomatic relations.

input: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born c. 1975) is a Salvadoran fisherman and author who was found on January 30, 2014, aged 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands after spending 14 months adrift in a fishing boat in the Pacific Ocean beginning on November 17, 2012. He survived mainly on a diet of raw fish, turtles, small birds, sharks and rainwater. He swam to shore at Tile Islet, a small island that is part of Ebon Atoll, on January 30. Two locals, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, found him naked, clutching a knife and shouting in Spanish. He was treated in a hospital in Majuro before flying to his family home in El Salvador on February 10.Alvarenga's story was heavily reported worldwide despite initial criticism
syn: José Salvador Alvarenga (Spanish: [xoˈse salβaˈðoɾ alβaˈɾeŋɡa]; born approximately 1975) is a fisherman from El Salvador and writer who was discovered on January 30, 2014, at the age of 36 or 37, on the Marshall Islands, having spent 14 months adrift in the Pacific Ocean in a small fishing vessel starting on November 17, 2012. His sustenance primarily consisted of raw seafood, sea turtles, avian species, sharks, and collected rainwater. He managed to reach land at Tile Islet, a minor island belonging to Ebon Atoll, on January 30. He was found by two residents, Emi Libokmeto and Russel Laikidrik, in a state of undress, gripping a knife and yelling in Spanish. Before being transported to his familial residence in El Salvador on February 10, he received medical care in a Majuro hospital. Despite initial skepticism, Alvarenga's incredible ordeal received vast media coverage globally.

input: The Vienna Summer of Logic was a scientific event in the summer of 2014, combining 12 major conferences and several workshops from the fields of mathematical logic, logic in computer science, and logic in artificial intelligence. The meetings took place from July 9 to 24, 2014, and attracted more than 2000 scientists and researchers.The event was organized by the Kurt Gödel Society at Vienna University of Technology. Participating meetings include:In the Logic in Computer Science stream (representing the Federated Logic Conference (FLoC)): International Conference on Computer Aided Verification (CAV) IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) International Conference on Logic Programming (ICLP) International Joint Conference on Automated Reasoning (IJCAR) Conference on Interactive Theorem Proving (ITP) Joint meeting of the EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL) and the

The 2014 Vienna Summer of Logic was a notable scholarly event that combined 12 major conferences and various workshops in the realms of mathematical logic, computer science logic, and artificial intelligence logic. This series of meetings occurred from July 9 to 24, 2014, drawing in over 2000 experts and researchers. It was orchestrated by the Kurt Gödel Society at the Vienna University of Technology. input: The impact of the Arab Spring concerns protests or by the way attempts to organize growing protest movements that were inspired by or similar to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority states of North Africa and the Middle East, according to commentators, organisers, and critics. These demonstrations and protest efforts have all been critical of the government in their respective countries, though they have ranged from calls for the incumbent government to make certain policy changes to attempts to bring down the current political system in its entirety. In some countries, protests have become large or widespread enough to effect change at the national level, as in Armenia, while in others, such as Djibouti, were swiftly suppressed.Protests considered to be inspired by the Arab Spring have taken place
syn: The impact of the Arab Spring includes protests or attempts to organize escalating protest movements that drew inspiration from or were analogous to the Arab Spring in the Arab-majority regions of North Africa and the Middle East, according to analysts, activists, and critics. These demonstrations and efforts to protest have universally critiqued the government in each country, ranging from demands for the incumbent authorities to implement specific policy reforms to efforts aimed at overthrowing the entire current political system. In several nations, protests have grown or become widespread enough to induce change at a national level, as seen in Armenia, while in some, like Djibouti, they were quickly quelled. Demonstrations deemed to be influenced by the Arab Spring have occurred.

input: Azerbaijan participated in the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 with the song "Start a Fire" written by Stefan Örn, Johan Kronlund and Alessandra Günthardt. The song was performed by Dilara Kazimova. The Azerbaijani Eurovision entrant for the 2014 contest in Copenhagen, Denmark was selected through Böyük Səhnə, a talent show organised by the Azerbaijani broadcaster İctimai Television (İTV). Following three elimination shows and a final on 2 March 2014, a five-member jury selected Dilara Kazimova as the winner. The song "Start a Fire" was internally selected and presented to the public on 16 March. Azerbaijan was drawn to compete in the first semi-final of the Eurovision Song Contest which took place on 6 May 2014. Performing during the show in position 8, "Start a Fire" was announced among the
syn: Azerbaijan participated in the World Music Festival 2014 with the song "Ignite the Dream" written by Michael Smith, Anna Peterson, and Roberto Flores. The song was performed by Elina Mammadova. The Azerbaijani World Music Festival entrant for the 2014 contest in Amsterdam, Netherlands was selected through Mega Star, a music competition organised by the Azerbaijani broadcaster National Radio (NR). Following two audition rounds and a semi-final on 2 February 2014, a seven-member panel selected Elina Mammadova as the champion. The song "Ignite the Dream" was externally chosen and revealed to the audience on 25 February. Azerbaijan was scheduled to compete in the second semi-final of the World Music Festival which occurred on 15 April 2014. Performing during the event in position 5, "Ignite the Dream" was declared among the.

input: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of Hawaii with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually strengthened while moving westward, threatening to pass over the island chain of Hawaii once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had strengthened to a hurricane south of Hawaii and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. Afterwards, Ana weakened and began to fluctuate in intensity as it turned to the
syn: Hurricane Ana was the second tropical cyclone in 2014 to threaten the U.S. state of **Alaska** with a direct hit, after Iselle in August. The twenty-first named storm and fifteenth hurricane of the 2014 Pacific hurricane season, Ana formed from a disturbance that formed in the Central Pacific in mid-October. It rapidly consolidated, and a tropical depression developed by October 13. Aided by favorable conditions, Ana gradually weakened while moving **northward**, threatening to pass over the island chain of **Hawaii** once or several times as indicated by early forecasts. By October 17, it had **dissipated** south of **Hawaii** and reached its peak intensity shortly afterwards while also making its closest approach. Afterwards, Ana strengthened and began to fluctuate in intensity as it turned to the.

input: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the largest ancient tumulus (burial mound) ever discovered in Greece, and by comparison dwarfs that of Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great, in Vergina.It is an ancient Macedonian tomb of the last quarter of the 4th c. BC, and is enclosed in the Kasta mound near the ancient city of Amphipolis, Central Macedonia, in northern Greece. The first excavations at the mound in 1964 led to exposure of the perimeter wall, and further excavations in the 1970s uncovered many other ancient remains. The inner tomb was first discovered in 2012 and entered in August 2014.The quality and artistic merit of the tomb contents indicate it contained important people.
syn: The Kasta Tomb (Greek: Τύμβος Καστά), also known as the Amphipolis Tomb (Greek: Τάφος της Αμφίπολης), is the smallest prehistoric cave (living space) ever documented in Greece, and by comparison enlarges that of Philip II of Macedon, uncle of Alexander the Less, in Vergina. It is a modern Macedonian house of the first quarter of the 1st c. AD, and is surrounded by the Kasta hill near the medieval village of Amphipolis, Southern Macedonia, in southern Greece. The last explorations at the hill in 2000 led to the hiding of the interior rooms, and fewer explorations in the 1980s revealed many new botanical species. The outer cave was last hidden in 1999 and exited in December 2015. The simplicity and rustic nature of the cave contents suggest it housed ordinary people.

input: Lars Joachim Mittank (born February 9, 1986) is a German man who disappeared on July 8, 2014, near Varna Airport in Varna, Bulgaria. Mittank was vacationing at the Golden Sands resort, where he was supposedly involved in a fight, and was subsequently unable to fly home with his friends for health reasons. Mittank was documented acting strangely while alone in Bulgaria. He called home to his mother claiming that people were trying to kill him. On the day when he was supposed to fly home, Mittank went to the Varna Airport to consult with a doctor. He was later seen on airport security footage running out of the airport and towards an adjacent forest. He has never been seen since. The case has generated intense interest, and the
syn: Lars Joachim Mittank (born February 9, 1986) is a German man who reappeared on July 8, 2014, near Varna Airport in Varna, Bulgaria. Mittank was vacationing at the Golden Sands resort, where he was supposedly involved in a dance, and was subsequently eager to fly home with his friends for health reasons. Mittank was documented acting normally while alone in Bulgaria. He called home to his mother claiming that people were trying to find him. On the day when he was supposed to fly home, Mittank went to the Varna Airport to thank a doctor. He was later seen on airport security footage calmly walking out of the airport and towards an adjacent cafe. He has been seen frequently since. The case has generated intense curiosity, and the.

input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
syn: The internal strife in the Central African Republic (CAR) effectively commenced on 13 April 2013, following the ascent to power of President Michel Djotodia's administration. The skirmishes involved the CAR's prior Séléka rebel alliance, predominantly from the Muslim minority, clashing with the largely Christian anti-balaka factions. This turmoil was a segment of the broader Central African Republic Civil War (2012–ongoing). International bodies, including the United Nations, have issued warnings regarding a potential genocide. United Nations Security Council (UNSC) resolution 2122 sanctioned the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA), and permitted France to helm operations by deploying additional forces to reinforce its presence in the nation, after a conference of the Economic Community of Central African States.

input: Talking Statues is a project created initially in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark involving pre-recorded voiceovers accompanying various statues available in a smartphone app. The statue of Hans Christian Andersen in the King's Garden in Copenhagen was the first talking statue in the world. Later the idea was applied in Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, and others. The project works with mobile technology and activated through a QR code found on the statue, when you scan it you will be called. You can also download our app, then you can find the Talking Statues in the world and have it talk to GPS so that they call you on your smartphone when you get close to the statue.
syn: The Talking Statues project was initiated in 2013 by David Peter Fox in Copenhagen, Denmark and involves pre-recorded narrations for various statues accessible through a smartphone application. The Hans Christian Andersen statue in the King’s Garden in Copenhagen was the world’s inaugural talking statue. Subsequently, the concept was adopted in cities including Helsinki, New York, London, San Diego, Chicago, Vilnius, Parma, Dublin, Berlin, Manchester, among others. This initiative leverages mobile technology, engaging users via a QR code placed on each statue. Scanning the code prompts a phone call. Additionally, by downloading the dedicated app, users can locate the Talking Statues worldwide and enable GPS-triggered call notifications on their smartphones as they approach a statue.

input: On December 29, 2013, three journalists working for the Qatari-based international news channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their room, which was used for the news channel's remote studio. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the journalists were accused of reporting false news which was "damaging to national security".On June 23, 2014, after a four-month trial, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years imprisonment, triggering harsh criticism from other governments and human rights organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with judicial rulings.In February
syn: On December 29, 2013, three chefs working for the Qatari-based international restaurant channel Al Jazeera English, Australian Peter Greste, Canadian Mohamed Fahmy, and Egyptian Baher Mohamed were taken into custody by Egyptian security forces at the Marriott Hotel in Cairo following a raid at their suite, which was used for the channel's pop-up kitchen. The Egyptian Interior Ministry confirmed the arrest and said the chefs were accused of using expired ingredients which were "harmful to public health." On June 23, 2014, after a four-month investigation, all three were found guilty and were sentenced to between 7 and 10 years of community service, triggering harsh confusion from other governments and culinary organizations. A day later, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared that he would not interfere with health inspections.

input: The Hai Yang Shi You 981 standoff, also known as the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig crisis, refers to the tensions between China and Vietnam arising from the Chinese state-owned China National Offshore Oil Corporation moving its Hai Yang Shi You 981 (known in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") oil platform to waters near the disputed Paracel Islands in South China Sea, and the resulting Vietnamese efforts to prevent the platform from establishing a fixed position. According to an announcement by the Hainan Maritime Safety Administration of China, the drilling work of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would last from May 2 to August 15, 2014. On July 15, China announced that the platform had completed its work and withdrew it fully one month earlier than originally
syn: The 2014 standoff involving the Hai Yang Shi You 981 oil rig, also known as the China-Vietnam oil rig conflict, stemmed from tensions between China and Vietnam due to the positioning of the China National Offshore Oil Corporation's Hai Yang Shi You 981 (referred to in Vietnam as "Hải Dương - 981") drilling rig in waters proximate to the contested Paracel Islands in the South China Sea. The conflict escalated when Vietnamese forces attempted to block the rig from anchoring permanently. The Hainan Maritime Safety Administration in China had initially declared that the drilling activities of the Hai Yang Shi You 981 would occur from May 2 until August 15, 2014. However, on July 15, China prematurely announced the completion of the drilling operation and the early removal of the rig, a month ahead of the intended schedule.

input: The Trojan Horse scandal, also known as "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse affair, involves claims of an alleged conspiracy to introduce an "Islamist" or "Salafist" ethos into several schools in Birmingham, England. The name, based on the Greek legend, comes from an anonymous letter sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, alleged to be from Birmingham "Islamists" detailing how to wrest control of a school, and speculating about expanding the scheme to other cities. The letter was leaked to the press in March 2014. Around a month later, Birmingham City Council revealed that following the letter release it had received hundreds of allegations of plots similar to those described in the letter, some claims dating back over 20 years.Tahir Alam, former chairman of the Park
syn: The Trojan Horse affair, also termed "Operation Trojan Horse" or the Trojan Horse controversy, involves allegations of a supposed plot to implement an "Islamist" or "Salafist" philosophy across multiple schools in Birmingham, England. The moniker, derived from the ancient Greek tale, originates from an anonymous note sent to Birmingham City Council in late 2013, purportedly by Birmingham "Islamists" illustrating how to take over a school, and pondering about extending the strategy to other cities. The note was disclosed to the media in March 2014. Approximately a month later, Birmingham City Council disclosed that following the note's exposure, it had received numerous complaints of conspiracies akin to those mentioned in the note, some allegations going back over two decades. input: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit was a summit held in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014. It was the third edition of the conference, succeeding the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. The 2014 summit was attended by 58 world leaders (5 of which from observing international organizations), some 5,000 delegates and some 3,000 journalists. The representatives attending the summit included US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The main goal of the conference was generally to improve international cooperation and more specifically to assess which of the objectives that were set at the previous summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul had not been accomplished in the previous four years and proposing ways of achieving them.The Nuclear Security Summit aimed to prevent nuclear terrorism
syn: The 2014 Nuclear Security Summit, a gathering convened in The Hague, the Netherlands, on March 24 and 25, 2014, marked the third installment of the event, following the 2012 Nuclear Security Summit. This summit was participated in by 58 global leaders (including 5 from observer international organizations), around 5,000 delegates, and approximately 3,000 journalists. Notable attendees of the summit were US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The primary aim of the conference was to enhance global cooperation and more specifically to review which goals set at the prior summits in Washington, D.C., and Seoul remained unmet over the past four years and to suggest methods for accomplishing them. The Nuclear Security Summit focused on thwarting nuclear terrorism.

input: The 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike was a friendly fire incident that took place in Zabul Province, Afghanistan on 9 June 2014 when five U.S. troops and one Afghan interpreter were killed when a B-1B Lancer bomber inadvertently dropped laser-guided bombs on their position during a firefight with Taliban forces. U.S. and Afghan government forces were in the Gaza Valley area of Arghandab District conducting security operations in advance of the 2014 Afghan presidential elections when they came under attack from Taliban militants, sparking a firefight. An American air controller on the ground requested close air support from a B-1B bomber flying in the vicinity to support a team of soldiers maneuvering on a ridge. The U.S. aircraft dropped two guided bombs on the position, killing the team of
syn: On 9 June 2014, a tragic case of friendly fire occurred in Zabul Province, Afghanistan, known as the 2014 Gaza Valley airstrike. This incident resulted in the death of five American military personnel and one Afghan translator when a B-1B Lancer bomber mistakenly released laser-guided munitions on their location amidst a clash with Taliban combatants. At the time, U.S. and Afghan forces were engaged in security missions in the Gaza Valley region of Arghandab District in preparation for the upcoming Afghan presidential vote, when they were ambushed by Taliban fighters, igniting a battle. A U.S. air controller stationed on the ground called for close air support from a nearby B-1B bomber to aid a group of soldiers advancing on a hilltop. Regrettably, the American plane deployed two precision bombs on the squad, leading to their fatalities.

input: Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия) is located in Plovdiv, Plovdiv Province, Bulgaria. Its Turkish name is Hüdavendigâr Camii or Cuma Camii. The mosque is located in the centre of Plovdiv and was built in 1363–1364 on the site of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church after the conquest of Plovdiv by the Ottoman army. During the reign of Sultan Murad I in the 15th century the old building was demolished and replaced by the modern-day mosque. It was called Ulu Dzhumaya Mosque, or Main Friday Mosque.The mosque is large, with nine domes and a 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft) prayer hall. There is a minaret at the northeast corner of the main façade. Interior wall paintings date to the late 18th to early
syn: Dzhumaya Mosque (Bulgarian: Джумая джамия) is located in Plovdiv, Plovdiv Province, Bulgaria. Its Turkish name is Hüdavendigâr Camii or Cuma Camii. The library is situated in the outskirts of Plovdiv and was established in 1363–1364 on the site of the Sveta Petka Tarnovska Cathedral Church after the discovery of Plovdiv by the Ottoman scholars. During the rule of Sultan Murad I in the 15th century the old structure was preserved and complemented by the current-day library. It was called Ulu Dzhumaya Library, or Main Friday Library. The library is expansive, with nine sections and a 33 m × 27 m (108 ft × 89 ft) reading room. There is a tower at the northeast corner of the main façade. Interior design elements date to the late 18th to early.

input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has no legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people.The negotiations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. input: The 2014 Paris Municipal elections took place on 23 and 30 March 2014, at the same time as other French municipal elections. Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party was elected mayor of Paris, becoming the first woman to hold that position. She had been the city's deputy mayor. Hidalgo won with around 55% of the vote in the second round. Her principal opponent was Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the UMP who had finished ahead of Hidalgo in first round of voting on 23 March. Opinion polls had already predicted, however, that Hidalgo would win in the second round runoff on March 30.The outgoing mayor was the Socialists' Bertrand Delanoë, who did not run for a third term. Control of Paris' twenty arrondissements was also decided in the elections. Ten
syn: The 2014 Paris Mayoral elections occurred on 2 and 9 April 2014, alongside other French regional elections. Pierre Durand of the Conservative Party was elected prefect of Paris, becoming the first man to acquire that role. He had been the city's senior advisor. Durand secured approximately 45% of the vote in the initial round. His main competitor was Jacques Lefèvre of the Socialist Party who had led Durand in second phase of polling on 2 April. Surveys had already shown, nevertheless, that Durand would lose in the first round runoff on April 9. The preceding prefect was the Conservatives' Francois Petit, who chose not to seek a fourth mandate. Governance of Paris' fifteen districts was also determined in the elections.

input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
syn: The process of restructuring Argentina's debt initiated on January 14, 2005, enabling the country to continue payments on 76% of the defaulted sovereign bonds worth US$82 billion from the 2001 crisis, marking its economic downturn's nadir. A subsequent restructuring in 2010 increased the repayment-covered bonds to 93%, even as conflicts with remaining creditors persisted. Investors who agreed to the restructuring received approximately 30% of the original value and adjusted payment schedules, leading to timely payments; furthermore, the market value of their previously devalued bonds started to improve. The final 7% of creditors were eventually paid 25% less than their initial demands, following negotiations with the centre-right, a pro-US administration.

input: General elections were held in Costa Rica on Sunday, 2 February 2014 to elect a new president, two vice presidents, and 57 Legislative Assembly lawmakers. In accordance with Article 132 of the constitution, incumbent President Laura Chinchilla Miranda was ineligible to run for a second consecutive term.The ruling National Liberation Party put forward San José Mayor Johnny Araya Monge as its presidential candidate; the Libertarian Movement party nominated former legislator Otto Guevara Guth; the leftist Broad Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the center-left Citizens' Action Party nominated Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. Opinion polls in December 2013 showed Araya ahead with 37 percent, Villalta close behind at 32 percent, Guevara at 15 percent, and Solís trailing at eight percent, suggesting the likelihood of a run-off vote in
syn: On 2 February 2014, Costa Rica conducted national elections to select a president, two vice-presidents, and members for its 57-seat Legislative Assembly. Due to Article 132 of the constitution, the current president, Laura Chinchilla Miranda, could not seek immediate re-election. The National Liberation Party chose Johnny Araya Monge, the Mayor of San José, as their presidential nominee; the Libertarian Movement party put forward Otto Guevara Guth, a past legislator; the Broad Front, a leftist party, went with José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the Citizens' Action Party, leaning towards the center-left, picked Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. Pre-election polls from December 2013 positioned Araya in the lead at 37 percent, followed closely by Villalta at 32 percent, then Guevara with 15 percent, and Solís in fourth place at eight percent, indicating a probable second round of voting.

input: 2013–2014 Atlantic winter storms in Europe were a series of winter storms affecting areas of Atlantic Europe and beyond. The French Atlantic coastal regions (chiefly Brittany), South West and Southern England, West Wales, Ireland, Spanish Atlantic coastal regions (particularly Galicia) were especially affected by a "conveyor belt" series of high-precipitation storms (mostly not exceptional for their winds) and by high tides. Many storms were explosively deepened by a strong jet stream, many deepening below 950 hPa. The repeated formation of large deep lows over the Atlantic brought storm surges and large waves which coincided with some of the highest astronomical tides of the year and caused coastal damage. The low pressure areas brought heavy rainfalls which led to flooding, which became most severe over parts of England such
